pageContext.claim: “We've added something great to our portfolio by increasing exports of clean, beautiful coal by over 60 percent. Sixty percent.”
pageContext.analysis: Coal exports increased by 61 percent from 2016 to 2017, to about the level in 2014, according to the Energy Information Administration. But the United States did not export “clean coal.” There is no such thing as clean coal. It is rhetoric often used to describe carbon capture and storage, a technique to capture carbon emissions from power plants, transport it through pipelines and inject it deep into the ground to make oil wells more productive. This technology has been developing in the U.S. since 2015 but it remains expensive and not viable economically without being linked to an enhanced oil recovery project.
